intro: Crepis bakeri subsp. typica, commonly known as the typical Baker's cinquefoil, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Asteraceae and is characterized by its small, yellowish flowers and hairy, lance-shaped leaves. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine environments, thriving in well-drained soils. It has a compact growth habit and is often found in open grasslands or among scree slopes. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and specialized species.
